comments.commentBody: I loved Taxi as well. Great characters. Thanks, Deb. No naticks and only a few uses of Ms. Check. Fun Sunday puzzle.

Look at the nuclear fuel model. It works if nuclear fuel recycling is done by a government owned government operated plant.

We don't recycle nuclear fuel because it is valuable and people steal it. The place it went that it wasn't supposed to go to is Israel. This happened in a small town near Pittsburgh, PA circa 1970. A company called Numec was in the business of reprocessing nuclear fuel.

[I almost took a job there in 1968, designing a nuclear battery for a heart pacemaker. [A nuclear battery would have the advantage of lasting many times as long as any other battery, eliminating many surgeries to replace batteries.]]
Spent fuel should be recycled, not stored.
Numec did not have a reactor. Numec "lost" some nuclear fuel. It wound up in Israel. The Israelis fueled their nuclear short cycle plutonium239 plant to make their nuclear weapons by stealing nuclear "waste."

Israel is one of the few countries that does not have its own uranium mine, but they could get uranium out of sea water.

My solution would be to reprocess the fuel at a Government Owned Government Operated [GOGO] facility. At a GOGO plant, bureaucracy and the multiplicity of ethnicity and religion would disable the transportation of uranium to Israel or to any unauthorized place. Nothing heavier than a secret would get out.

It must be nice for you, Douthat, to never have to agonies about anything. All you have to do is cast aspersions, peddle innuendos, no facts needed. And, when you get called out, you cop out with, 'I was merely raising questions.'
You are wrong about Obama having the "world is battlefield agenda." Plain wrong.

"By the way, saw any .........books there?books there?"

'"inner-esting" or not, with "pitchers" or not ?
Are you kidding me?  what kind of nut job are you?

Yes, my name is Peterson, but I'm not connected 2 Pete peterson, and i agree with and like Krugman.But on Krugman's post today: I still say the deregulation of the airlines in the late 1970s was a mistake that led to 9/11, curtailment of civil liberties and damage to the Constitution, but our airlines still aren't safe. Because, airlines needed hefty profit margins to be able to spend a lot of $ on safety that they could then advertise. So they needed guaranteed moneymaking routes. Once the airlines were deregulated, it was hard to make $ and powerful shareholders were pressing airlines to shave on costs & safety. They competed on price instead.That's why, I think, there weren't doors on cockpits-it wouldn't have been hard, & prior to 9/11, a prescient stewardess pleaded with the executives to install doors, 2 no avail. There were lots of things that could have been done to prevent terrorism, but airlines, to save $, went for a pretense of prevention, by making a big deal of how alarmed they were whenever some 8 year old boy made a joke about a bomb on the plane-just public relations, pretending they cared.As I said, airlines still aren't safe and no one wants to get on one-it's a miserable experience. So instead,the rich have their Lear jets and chartered flights(on which, they have some control on who else is onboard-that makes it safer), and just as in 1976, it costs lots 2 get a decent safe flight.

"The UCS supports a national renewable energy standard" which would be ineffective. Too little too late.

"The UCS supports an increase in Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards" which would be ineffective. Too little too late.

These 2 statements from Wikipedia condemn the UCS or convict the UCS as being useless. Why bother? The UCS program is nothing more that another excuse to continue burning fossil fuels.

Don't be in awe of people. There are no worthy people. Be in awe of Nature.
"the last eighty" years is entirely within the time of human-caused GW.

I'm still stuck on college ball, watched UNC against NC State last night. A real battle of the pitchers. Watch for left-hander Carlos Rodon: as a freshman last year, 135 strikeouts in 117 innings pitched. (Not itched)

John,

The Giants won tonight with a walk-off inside-the-park home run in the 10th. I won't be online until tomorrow and I don't mean to put pressure on your avatar, but the bar is pretty high.

It has shown up with the false indication that it was posted a half hour ago.  So apologies if it duplicates points that others had posted in the interim.

Might someone in the tech dep't have a look at this?

-- ManyThanksFor [that]
I recall clearly that Ms. Dowd penned some pretty petty words about him during Gore's campaign.  One could conclude she helped elect Bush.

"We've had enough Bushes."
Well said and thank you Barbara Bush!

@ Jonathan:

If customers paid the taxes, as you suggest, then why do companies go to all the trouble and expenses (e.g., lobbying, lawyers, incorporation, etc.) of setting up structures to avoid paying taxes.

It seems the reason companies don't pay taxes is not for the reason you suggest, but because of all the tax loopholes that facilitate hiding corporate revenues in tax havens like Ireland.

The claim that companies don't pay taxes, but their customers do is just another ideological half-truth.

My comment has not shown up after 4 hours, but I think I said "strained" also!  Can't remember.  Maybe I said "forced".  I had a lot more to say.  Long story short, I think it's a gimmick that has a future if done well.
Barbara, exactly... Which is why I had SEN before DEM.
Simple? Oh, I see. A typo. You meant to write: simple-minded.
Couldn't agree more.  We don't call him Kontrarian Krugman for nothing.  If the Conservative mind is closed it is only to shut out tripe like his for the sake of our sensibilities.
We'd already be well on the way to an economic recovery had Romney been elected.

Oh for gods sake Krugman... Cut the corporate tax to 10% and re-appropriate the Feds payoffs to Wallstreet of $85 billion to small business in the form of equity-grants and America will boom within a year. Simple, yet from the broken logic of the liberal mind; totally impossible.

Yes, Barbara Boxer represents Martin's state in the U.S. Senate, and she is a Dem.

Robert's Senators are not. Each is a Rep.

If you want to be really confused: Besides Sens. Boxer and Feinstein, all the other Congresspeople from Martin's state are Reps. One might be a Dem., and another might be a Rep., but they're all Reps.

But "Boxer, in brief" is a Dem. A Dem. Sen. from CA or Cal. or Calif.

-- MTF

Chris Dudley: The consequences of nuclear war do not include the extinction of the human race [of chimpanzee]. I worked at the US army's lead lab for nuclear weapons effects. I know about the consequences of nuclear war. An Extinction Level Event [ELE] means 100 million megatons. At maximum, we and the USSR together had 1 part in ten thousand of one hundred million megatons.

Chris Dudley's father definitely had an emotional problem with nuclear anything that went way beyond reality. Irrational fear or irrational guilt?

Americans are paranoid about all things nuclear. NMR [Nuclear Magnetic Resonance] had to be renamed MRI [Magnetic Resonance Imaging] to get sick people into the scanner. It is the exact same machine. Only the sign has been changed. Apparently, the average American doesn't know that all matter, including people, is made of atoms and that atoms have nuclei. The NMR/MRI machine aligns the spins of the nuclei in the atoms in the patient using a big magnet. Since different atoms have different nuclear spin resonances, the NMR/MRI machine can see one element at a time.

Look up "fan death" in Korea.
http://bravenewclimate.com/2011/08/26/risk-fans-fission/

Even when playing well, Radwanska has never gone very far at the French Open.  Though her finesse game should theoretically be successful on clay, she has never been past the 4th round at Roland Garros.
You can't be serious that you didn't realize that was tongue in cheek.

Yes I understand there are many double blind statistically valid studies to support your view.

But I can't cite any - can you?

I can't cite any studies that support the opposite view, either. But I have this suspicion that beyond some minimal level of common sense our marvelously efficient digestive system is not all that picky about the types of calories it gets.

Too much food of any type may be bad for the athlete, but I doubt performance will vary with the substitution of pasta for pizza. I would be certain that the best advice would to avoid either for several hours before strenuous effort.

GG

Maybe he would perform even better with an eating plan that did include a bunch of healthful options to displace some of the fast foods. Yes, the quality of one's meals does often help determine the quality of one's play,
That does make me nuts too.
I agree!  "40 all", is not deuce either!  It's "40 all", then "add" to one or the other THEN deuce if it comes to that!  That's my scoring system anyway.  ;-)

I am the only one who is really annoyed when some people call "deuce" when the score is 30-all? I understand that in both 30-30 and 40-40 situations, one player must win two consecutive points to win the game, but still, deuce explains more about how the players got to that point.

Back in the middle sixties (before open tennis, when lots of famous players didn't  play for prize money), I once saw and heard Fred Stolle calling a match from the umpire's chair.  After a game had gone beyond deuce, he would say, "Advantage server" or "Advantage receiver."  Was this only used by Australians?  Or just by Fred?

Using 15 and 30 makes more sense then 1 and 2 because then you always know whether you are referring to the points or the games. If it was the other way you would say 2-1 and it could either refer to points or games. In addition to some players shortening 15 to 5, I once played with a guy that shortened 30 to 3. When it was 5-3 the guy with 3 was winning! Talk about spectator confusion.
